org.puredata.core

Class PdBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.puredata.core.PdBase

  • public final class PdBase
extends Object
    PdBase provides basic Java bindings for pd. Some random notes: - This is a low-level library that aims to leave most design decisions to higher-level code. In particular, it will throw no exceptions (except for the methods for opening files, which use instances of File and may throw IOException when appropriate). At the same time, it is designed to be fairly robust in that it is thread-safe and does as much error checking as I find reasonable at this level. Client code is still responsible for proper dimensioning of buffers and such, though. - The MIDI methods choose sanity over consistency with pd or the MIDI standard. To wit, channel numbers always start at 0, and pitch bend values are centered at 0, i.e., they range from -8192 to 8191. - The basic idea is to turn pd into a library that essentially offers a rendering callback (process) mimicking the design of JACK, the JACK Audio Connection Kit. - The release method is mostly there as a reminder that some sort of cleanup might be necessary; for the time being, it only releases the resources held by the print handler, closes all patches, and cancels all subscriptions. Shutting down pd itself wouldn't make sense because it might be needed in the future, at which point the native library may not be reloaded. - I'm a little fuzzy on how/when to use sys_lock, sys_unlock, etc., and so I decided to handle all synchronization on the Java side. It appears that sys_lock is for top-level locking in scheduling routines only, and so Java-side sync conveys the same benefits without the risk of deadlocks.
    Author:
    Peter Brinkmann (peter.brinkmann@gmail.com)

      • computeAudio

        public static void computeAudio(boolean state)
        same as "compute audio" checkbox in pd gui, or [;pd dsp 0/1( Note: Maintaining a DSP state that's separate from the state of the audio rendering thread doesn't make much sense in libpd. In most applications, you probably just want to call computeAudio(true) at the beginning and then forget that this method exists.
        Parameters:
        state -

      • release

        public static void release()
        releases resources held by native bindings (PdReceiver object and subscriptions); otherwise, the state of pd will remain unaffected Note: It would be nice to free pd's I/O buffers here, but sys_close_audio doesn't seem to do that, and so we'll just skip this for now.

        Parameters:

      • openAudio

        public static int openAudio(int inputChannels,
            int outputChannels,
            int sampleRate,
            int ticksPerBuffer)
        sets up pd audio; must be called before process callback
        Parameters:
        inputChannels -
        outputChannels -
        sampleRate -
        ticksPerBuffer - number of pd ticks per process call
        Returns:
        error code, 0 on success

      • processRaw

        public static int processRaw(float[] inBuffer,
             float[] outBuffer)
        raw process callback, processes one pd tick, writes raw data to buffers without interlacing
        Parameters:
        inBuffer - must be an array of the right size, never null; use inBuffer = new short[0] if no input is desired
        outBuffer - must be an array of size outBufferSize from openAudio call
        Returns:
        error code, 0 on success

        source - array in Pd to read from
        srcOffset - index at which to start reading
        n - number of values to read
        Returns:
        0 on success, or a negative error code on failure

        Returns:

                int value)

        Parameters:
        channel - starting at 0
        value - -8192..8191 (note that Pd has some offset bug in its pitch bend objects, but libpd corrects for this)
        Returns:
        error code, 0 on success
